page.title: 06Burreldale Moss in Bourtie
page.content: Peat as a fuel has traditionally been harvested from the Burreldale Moss on the edge of Bourtie parish. The main portion of the Moss, however, lies within the parish of keithhall and Kinkell. Residents have by tradition the right to cast (dig) their own peat for private use, but only one farmer now does this. The method used consists of removing the top layer of turf and heather; then peat is cast in rectangular chunks measuring 2 x 1 ft. Starting at the surface and working downwards on a peat face approximately five feet long. The best peat is found in the lower layers. The peat blocks are then set up in pyramidal stacks or rickles to dry for a week and then removed to the farm for stacking outside in peat walls. Peat stacked outside burns better than peat from inside a shed.
